course.subject: FINA
course.name: Banking and Financial Intermediation
course.description: This course examines financial intermediaries with a particular emphasis on banks. It introduces students to the nature, purpose, and management of these institutions. The course also brings together the upstream issues in risk measurement and the regulative environment surrounding banks. By the end of this course, students will be able to understand the role of banks in the economy and the effects of frictions such as information asymmetry and agency costs on bank behavior. The course will start with the review of basic game theory.
course.prerequisites: FINA 2203 OR FINA 2303

reviews.author: Arange
reviews.comment_content:
This course is mainly focusing on risks faced by commercial banks. Most of contents are calculations but all of them are simple. It does not require much mathematical background.

Ch1 Introduction
Ch2 Game Theory
Ch3 Maturity Transformation
Ch4 Relationship Banking, Credit Rationing, Screening, and Delegated Monitoring
Ch5 Bank Regulation
Ch6 Bank Competition
Ch7 Bank Networds
Ch8 Financial Crisis

Basically, most of the topics except Bank Regulation are related to calculations. Midterm tests up to chapter 4 credit rationing. The course contents involve many assumptions but you still can learn the mechanisms of the commercial banks such as the InterBank market, how bank set interest rate.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor's teaching is great. The lecture notes are mostly problems with lots of space which you need to copy the answer in class. In other words, you are not recommended to skip any lecture. In midterm and final, all of the questions are similar to the problems in homework and in class. Make sure you have copied the correct answer so that you can understand the problem in exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite standard for a normal finance course with mean around C+.

Assignments X 3   25%
Midterm                 25%
Final                      50%

As the whole content is designed by Prof Okat, all the questions are specifically designed by professor. In other words, you cannot find any clue or answer from the Internet for the homework questions.

Assignment 1  Mean 6/6
Assignment 2  Mean 7/9
Assignment 3  Mean 8.6/10
Midterm           Mean 19.5/25
Final                Mean 38.55/50
Total                Mean 79.65/100

Also, professor used a very special way to grade your assignment and exam. He makes the point of each question to around only 1-2 point. When the final answer is wrong, you get no mark. This makes the mark in midterm and final exams so low even though the content is easy.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is low as there is only three pieces of assignments during the semester. However, as the mean of assignment is quite high, you need to be careful. You only need to repeatedly do the questions in the lecture notes and in the homework. You do not need to buy the textbook as it is useless. All the content is designed by Prof. and there is no extra exercise for you to practice the calculations problem.

reviews.author: Hansen
reviews.title: Interesting course, not really good grade
reviews.comment_content:
At the start of the course, you will familiar with some basic mathematics. Then he will apply those mathematics into some situation, for example, moral hazard and adverse selection. After that, he will link those situation into the reality environment.
Mainly talk about banking knowledge like CAR. practical as well.
reviews.comment_teaching: Clear and interesting. Throughout the course I seldom skip any lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
Normal grading.
All homework at least average score, perform poorly in mid term (below 2 SD), above average in final, and I got a B-.
What I suggest is don't lose too much mark in mid term. It matters a lot.
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload, 1 homework every 2 weeks. You can form a group of 4 to finish it.

reviews.author: yup
reviews.title: Great course with good grades
reviews.comment_content:
Started off with game theory and moved on to hypothetical scenarios regarding banks.
Examples in class are pretty easy to follow and you can definitely understand it if you follow the prof train of thought
Content may be a little too basic for a 4000+ course
reviews.comment_teaching:
The prof goes super slow and explains everything step by step during class to make sure everyone follows.
Content for each lesson is quite little so he almost always release the class early.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not the best grading, full marks for midterm and final but still just a A-
On the other hand prof specifically stated that he won't fail anyone
reviews.comment_workload:
3 questions sets, one midterm, one final
Midterm and final problems are very similar to the question sets, so just revise the question sets before the exams and you can do pretty well.

reviews.author: uni
reviews.comment_content:
The course will start by the review of Game Theory and the optimization problem. These content will be applied in the latter topic in the course.

There are also other topics such as Maturity Transformation, Relationship banking, Credit rationing, Screening and Monitoring, Bank regulation, Bank competition, and Financial crisis. You will develop a sense of quantitative reasoning in coping with the banking problem in real life.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is nice and willing to take questions after class. He would address every question thoroughly. During class, his explanation of complicated concepts is clear and he would use some calculation examples to illustrate the ideas.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading component:
1. HW x 3 (25%)
Mean:
HW1 - 6.4/7
HW2 - 6.3/8
HW3 - 9.5/10
2. Mid-term exams (25%) - 4 questions
Mean: 17.2/25
3. Final exams (50%) - 5 questions
Mean: 39.09/50

Some of the homework questions are from the previous exams questions.

Exams is non-cumulative.

This is a normal finance course. Grade lying around mean is C+/B-.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not really high. There is only 3 homework, a mid-term exams and a final exams.

However, you have to spend extra time to practice the questions in the slides repeatedly. Since this is a good practice and preparation for your mid-term and final exams. Don't forget to redo the homework again before the exams. The questions are similar to what you have solved.
